summary: This FBI electronic communication encloses and summarizes Virgin Islands Daily News articles from May 26 and June 13, 2023. The articles report on a court filing by JPMorgan Chase's lawyers accusing former Virgin Islands First Lady Cecile deJongh of acting as Jeffrey Epstein's 'local fixer,' facilitating his abuse by influencing politicians, arranging student visas for victims, and even soliciting his input on sex offender law revisions.

keyFacts: A court filing by JPMorgan Chase lawyers accuses former USVI First Lady Cecile deJongh of being Jeffrey Epstein's 'primary conduit' and 'local fixer' for two decades.

The filing alleges deJongh told Epstein which government officials to pay off and devised ways to justify his victims' presence by enrolling them at the University of the Virgin Islands for student visas.
DeJongh allegedly asked Epstein, a registered sex offender, to suggest changes to the territory's sex offender law in 2011 and apologized when not all his revisions were included.
UVI President David Hall denied all allegations in the bank's filing regarding the university's involvement.
